subject: Re: [junit] How to test private methods in a class.

messageBody:
Hi,

I don't agree with this. Imagine that you have class with one point of entry
for the client i.e. one public method. You can't change the access modifier
of your method just to test it. Wrapping your private method in a public
method is just the same as changing the access modifier. It is will
documented and it works to use java reflection.

The developers in the project I am currently working changed their private
methods to public just to UNIT test their code. It is currently very
important to test the private methods as it accounts for over 60% of the
functionality and logic. I have found that enables me to test bottom up and
I have more confidence when coding and when I need to refactor.

I have posted the SecureClassAccess.java in the "files" section of group for
anyone that does want to us it to test their private methods.

A+ David

On 30/08/05, Richa Kishore <brajkiricha@...> wrote:
>
> You can't test a private method directly in JUnit.
>
> A method is private, it means the business of the
> method is specific to the class only.
>
> SO, if you want to test a private method write a
> poublic method, which is calling the private method
> and then write a junit test for this new public
> method.
>
>
